doc.field: Cerro Cabrillo - as seen from the Quarry Trail, on a docent-led walk by Norma Wightman 04 Feb 2011, Morro Bay, CA. Info: <a href"http:www.slostateparks.commorro_baymb_hikingtrails_nature.asp" rel"nofollow">CA State Park's<a> Cerro Cabrillo in Morro Bay, CA., one of the <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html" rel"nofollow">Nine (Seven) Sisters<a> also called <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo" rel"nofollow">Cabrillo Peak<a>. The Sierra Club <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo" rel"nofollow">santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo <a> says " Cerro Cabrillo is the third visible volcanic cone, or butte, southeast of Morro Rock. It is located within the section of Morro Bay State Park bordered by Turri Road, South Bay Boulevard and Chorro Creek. Cerro Cabrillo's elevation is 911 feet and provides a moderately strenuous hike with some truly delightful views of the Morro Bay Estuary and the remaining chain of the Nine Sisters. It was named by Mrs. Louisiana Clayton Dart in 1964 in honor of the famous Portuguese explorer, Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo, sailing for the Spanish crown, who was known to be in the vicinity in 1542. More related photos from a hike actually up to the summit, on 23 April 2009 <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosmikebairdsets72157617153355303">www.flickr.comphotosmikebairdsets72157617153355303<a> . Photo © 2011 “Mike” Michael L. Baird, mike {at] mikebaird d o t com, flickr.bairdphotos.com, Canon EOS 5D Mark II 21.1MP Full Frame CMOS Digital SLR Camera with EF 24-105mm f4 L IS USM Lens, handheld, RAW. To use this photo, see access, attribution, and commenting recommendations at <a href"http:www.flickr.compeoplemikebaird#credit">www.flickr.compeoplemikebaird#credit<a> - Please add commentsnotestags to add to or correct information, identification, etc. <i>Please, no comments or invites with gaudy badges, unrelated images, flashing icons, multiple invites, or invites with award levels andor awardpost rules. <i> Critique is always welcomed.
statepark hike docent cerrocabrillo quarrytrail mikebaird normawightman 04feb2011
Cerro Cabrillo - as seen from the Quarry Trail, on a docent-led walk by Norma Wightman 04 Feb 2011, Morro Bay, CA

Cerro Cabrillo Hike. MMI FMM Self-portrait Mike Baird for my mom. 2009-11-14-Cerro-Cabrillo-LOF - <a href"http:www.losososfitness.com" rel"nofollow">Los Osos Fitness,<a> Los Osos, CA., sponsors <a href"http:www.losososfitness.comevents.php" rel"nofollow">a monthly hike<a> - today's hike, 14 Nov 2009 takes us to the top of <a href"http:www.slostateparks.commorro_baymb_hikingtrails_nature.asp" rel"nofollow">CA State Park's<a> Cerro Cabrillo in Morro Bay, CA., one of the <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html" rel"nofollow">Nine (Seven) Sisters<a> also called <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo" rel"nofollow">Cabrillo Peak<a>. Our leaders are the affable Chris and Elyse Ungar to who we own many thanks for so many wonderful hikes and companionship, and <i>fitness<i>. Photos and videos in this set wee taken by Michael "Mike" L. Baird, mike at mikebaird d o t com, flickr.bairdphotos.com, on either an iPhone 3GS or Canon S90 compact camera. About 18 people came on today's hike, which took us up to <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosmikebairdsets72157617153355303">"Tiki" Rock<a> on the north-east side of the dual-peaked Cabrillo Peak mountain formation. The Sierra Club <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo" rel"nofollow">santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo<a> says " Cerro Cabrillo is the third visible volcanic cone, or butte, southeast of Morro Rock. It is located within the section of Morro Bay State Park bordered by Turri Road, South Bay Boulevard and Chorro Creek. Cerro Cabrillo's elevation is 911 feet and provides a moderately strenuous hike with some truly delightful views of the Morro Bay Estuary and the remaining chain of the Nine Sisters. It was named by Mrs. Louisiana Clayton Dart in 1964 in honor of the famous Portuguese explorer, Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo, sailing for the Spanish crown, who was known to be in the vicinity in 1542. More related photos from the same hike on 23 April 2009 <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosmikebairdsets72157617153355303">www.flickr.comphotosmikebairdsets72157617153355303<a> .

Tiki Rock on Cerro Cabrillo Peak. Cerro Cabrillo (Cerro Peak), Morro Bay, CA 23 April 2007. Mike Baird and Nick Richardson brave 1000's of ticks and ample poison oak, to hike up to "Tiki Rock" on the summit of Cerro Cabrillo, one of the Seven Sisters (Nine Sisters) Morros in San Luis Obispo County <a href"http:morro-bay.comoutdoorcabrillo">morro-bay.comoutdoorcabrillo<a> . <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo">santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo<a> says "Cerro Cabrillo is the third visible volcanic cone, or butte, southeast of Morro Rock. It is located within the section of Morro Bay State Park bordered by Turri Road, South Bay Boulevard and Chorro Creek. Cerro Cabrillo's elevation is 911 feet and provides a moderately strenuous hike with some truly delightful views of the Morro Bay Estuary and the remaining chain of the Nine Sisters. It was named by Mrs. Louisiana Clayton Dart in 1964 in honor of the famous Portuguese explorer, Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo, sailing for the Spanish crown, who was known to be in the vicinity in 1542." Snapshot by Michael "Mike" L. Baird, mike at mikebaird d o t com, flickr.bairdphotos.com, Nikon P6000 with built-in GPS measurement, handheld.

Cerro Cabrillo's elevation is 911 feet and provides a moderately strenuous hike with some truly delightful views of the Morro Bay Estuary and the remaining chain of the Nine Sisters. It was named by Mrs. Louisiana Clayton Dart in 1964 in honor of the famous Portuguese explorer, Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo, sailing for the Spanish crown, who was known to be in the vicinity in 1542. Morro Bay Estuary from Cerro Cabrillo (Cerro Peak), Morro Bay, CA 23 April 2007. Mike Baird and Nick Richardson Hike

Black Hill (left) and Cerro Cabrillo (right) Reflect in glassy calm waters of the Morro Bay CA Estuary, where three White-faced Ibis can be seen where the reflection of the base of Cerro Cabrillo in the water meets the green pickle weed salt marsh vegetation. 02Oct2009. It is unusual to observe Ibis birds in this location. On this kayak birding outing, Norma Wightman and I (Mike Baird) saw these birds from some long distance away, as we did not want to disturb them. Photo by Michael "Mike" L. Baird, mike [at} mikebaird d o t com, flickr.bairdphotos.com; using a little rugged Canon D10 waterproof camera.
black birds reflections bay wildlife hill estuary ibis cerro morrobay reflexions morro cabrillo d10 blackhill cerrocabrillo kayakmorrobay 02oct2009
Black Hill (left) and Cerro Cabrillo (right) Reflect in glassy calm waters of the Morro Bay CA Estuary, where three White-faced Ibis can be seen

Mike Baird self-portrait on the summit of Cerro Cabrillo (Cerro Peak), Morro Bay, CA 23 April 2007. Mike Baird and Nick Richardson brave 1000's of ticks and ample poison oak, to hike up to "Tiki Rock" on the summit of Cerro Cabrillo, one of the Seven Sisters (Nine Sisters) Morros in San Luis Obispo County <a href"http:morro-bay.comoutdoorcabrillo">morro-bay.comoutdoorcabrillo<a> . <a href"http:santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo">santalucia.sierraclub.orgninesis.html#cabrillo<a> says "Cerro Cabrillo is the third visible volcanic cone, or butte, southeast of Morro Rock. It is located within the section of Morro Bay State Park bordered by Turri Road, South Bay Boulevard and Chorro Creek. Cerro Cabrillo's elevation is 911 feet and provides a moderately strenuous hike with some truly delightful views of the Morro Bay Estuary and the remaining chain of the Nine Sisters. It was named by Mrs. Louisiana Clayton Dart in 1964 in honor of the famous Portuguese explorer, Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo, sailing for the Spanish crown, who was known to be in the vicinity in 1542." Snapshot by Michael "Mike" L. Baird, mike at mikebaird d o t com, flickr.bairdphotos.com, Nikon P6000 with built-in GPS measurement, handheld.
